Module kivakit.core.kernel
Package com.telenav.kivakit.core.kernel.data.validation.ensure

Class Ensure

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.telenav.kivakit.core.kernel.data.validation.ensure.Ensure
  • public class Ensure
extends java.lang.Object
    A class for providing flexibility and consistency in the checking of states and parameters. There are multiple kinds of validation tools available in the Java environment, including manual checks, exceptions, assertions, loggers, Objects.require*, JUnit assertions and others. This class provides a consistent, abstracted interface to this functionality, such that all messages are formatted using MessageFormatter and the kind of failure reporting can be changed at runtime for different classes of failures.

    An application can specify what kind of reporting it wants by calling reporter(Class, ValidationReporter), passing in the class of failure and the ValidationReporter that should be used to report it.

    Failure Types

    • Failure - A generic failure message reported by fail(String, Object...)
    • ValidationProblem - An ensure failure reported by one of the ensure() methods
    • Unsupported - An unsupported operation reported by unsupported(String, Object...)

    Validation Reporters

    The BaseValidationReporter subclasses used by Validator are used to report Ensure failures as well.

    • AssertingValidationReporter - Fails with a Java assertion
    • LogValidationReporter - Logs the failure
    • NullValidationReporter - Does nothing
    • ThrowingValidationReporter - Throws a ValidationFailure exception

    Default Reporting

    All failure types are linked to the ThrowingValidationReporter by default.

    Ensure Methods

    The method ensure(boolean, String, Object...) will report an ValidationProblem if the given boolean condition value is false. Other convenience methods include:

    • ensure(boolean, Throwable, String, Object...)
    • ensure(boolean)
    • ensure(boolean, String, Object...)
    • ensure(Supplier, String, Object...)
    • ensureNotNull(Object)
    • ensureNotNull(Object, String, Object...)
    • ensureEqual(Object, Object)
    • ensureEqual(Object, Object, String, Object...)

    Examples:

     ensure(x < 100);
 ensure(x < 100, "The value $ is not less than 100", x);
 ensure(() -> computeX() < 100);
 ensure(() -> isValid(), "$ is not valid", name());
 ensureEqual(a, b, "Point $ is not equal to point $", a, b);

    Fail Methods

    Methods are provided to report outright failures with a Failure message:

    • fail() - Fails with a generic message
    • fail(String, Object...) - Fails with the formatted message
    • fail(Throwable, String, Object...) - Fails with the formatted message

    Unsupported Methods

    Unsupported operations are reported with an Unsupported message:

    • unsupported() - Reports an unsupported operation with an Unsupported message
    • unsupported(String, Object...) - Reports an unsupported operation with an Unsupported message

    Exception-Throwing Methods

    Methods are also provided to throw two common exceptions:

    • illegalState(String, Object...) - Throws a formatted IllegalStateException
    • illegalArgument(String, Object...) - Throws a formatted IllegalArgumentException

    Examples:

     unsupported();
 illegalArgument("$ should be between $ and $", x, minimum, maximum);
 illegalState("Must be initialized to add elements");
 int size() { return unsupported(); }
    Author:
    jonathanl (shibo)
    See Also:
    Logger, Warning, MessageFormatter, Message.format(String, Object...)

      • reporterFactory

        public static void reporterFactory​(MapFactory<java.lang.Class<? extends Message>,​ValidationReporter> factory)
        Changes the factory being used to map message types to validation reporters on a per-thread basis. Note that this method should only be called once at the start of a program. Calling it again can result in unpredictable results because the method clears the thread-local map from message type to reporter and other threads might be using values in the map.

      • unsupported

        public static <T> T unsupported()

        public static <T> T unsupported​(java.lang.String message,
